solution.text:
let \(\sqrt {_{j}_}\) be a rational number
\(\Rightarrow \sqrt {_{j}_}\) can be represented as \(\frac ab\), where a and b are coprime
\(\Rightarrow _{j}_=\frac {a^2}{b^2}\)
\(\Rightarrow _{j}_\times b^2 =a^2\)
\(\Rightarrow \sqrt {_{j}_}\times b = a\) and \(_{j}_\) divides \(a^2\)
As _{j}_=p(say) is a prime number we can use the theorem that says, if p divides \(a^2\) it will also divide \(a\)
let c be the factor by which _{j}_ divides a
\(\Rightarrow _{j}_\times c= a\)
on putting the value of \(a\) we get, \(_{j}_\times c=\sqrt {_{j}_}\times b\)
on squaring and solving we get, \(_{j}_\times c^2=b^2\)
\(\Rightarrow _{j}_\, divides \,b^2\)
from the previously mentioned theorem, we can say
\(_{j}_ \, divides\, b \)
This contradicts the assumption that \(a\) and \(b\) are coprime
therefore,\( \sqrt {_{j}_}\) s an irrational number
On simplifying \(t=\sqrt {_{j}_}\times \sqrt {_{j}_}\)
we get \(t=\sqrt {_{j}_\times _{j}_}=_{j}_\)
_{j}_ is an integer and every integer is a rational number

content.text:
Find whether \(\sqrt _{j}_\) is an irrational number or not.
Also comment about the rationality of \(t=\sqrt {_{j}_}\times \sqrt {_{j}_}\)
